text: In vivo inhibition of NF-kappa B in T-lineage cells leads to a dramatic decrease in cell proliferation and cytokine production and to increased cell apoptosis in response to mitogenic stimuli , but not to abnormal thymopoiesis .

To understand the role of NF-kappa B complexes in T cell development and activation , we have generated transgenic mice in which <extra_id_0> RelA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complexes were selectively inhibited in the T-lineage cells by specific expression of a trans-dominant form of <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Transgene expression did not affect the thymic development , but led to lowered numbers of splenic T cells and to a dramatic decrease in the ex vivo proliferative response of splenic T lymphocytes .

Analysis of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-2R alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression demonstrated that the perturbation of the proliferation response was not attributable to an abnormal expression of these genes .

text: The proliferative deficiency of the transgenic T cells was associated with an increased apoptosis .

These results point out the involvement of NF-kappa B / Rel family proteins in growth signaling pathways by either regulating proteins involved in the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling or by functionally interfering with the cell cycle progression .
